abstract: The Season 3 premiere of HBO's "Bored to Death" on Monday reunites viewers with Jonathan, Ray and George in contemporary boho New York where they all struggle with various sorts of daddy issues.
snippet: The Season 3 premiere of HBO's "Bored to Death" on Monday reunites viewers with Jonathan, Ray and George in contemporary boho New York where they all struggle with various sorts of daddy issues.
lead_paragraph: There's no other comedy on television quite like HBO's "Bored to Death." It's simultaneously old-fashioned and amazingly up to the minute, a gumshoe fantasy set in a very real world: the Brooklyn brownstones and cafes and Manhattan co-op apartments and watering holes that shelter what passes for literary culture in 21st-century New York. The novelist Jonathan Ames, the show's creator, works out his love-hate relationship to the city's writing life (and those who live it) with a mix of whimsy and precise observation that can make even the most cleverly written network sitcoms -- "Modern Family," "Community" -- seem mass produced and one-size-fits-all in comparison.
